tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

Possible meanings are 1) "song people sang while going up to Jerusalem for a celebration" or 2) "song people sang while going up the steps into the temple" or 3) "song whose words are like steps." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:120:001|120:1]]

tn.ref: Those who trust in Yahweh are like Mount Zion, unshakable, forever enduring
tn.text: People who trust in Yahweh are spoken of as if they they were Mount Zion. Mountains are unable to be moved.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: As the mountains surround Jerusalem, so Yahweh surrounds his people
tn.text: Yahweh's protection is spoken of as if he was the mountains surrounding Jerusalem. Jerusalem was surrounded by several mountains, which protected it from attack. AT: "As the hills that surround Jerusalem protect it, so Yahweh protects his people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Here the scepter of wickedness represents the rule of wicked people. AT: "Wicked people" or "Wicked rulers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This is a request. The abstract noun "good" can be stated as an action. AT: "Yahweh, Please do good things" or "Yahweh, I beg you to do good things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here, "hearts" refers to their desires. AT: "desire to do the right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Refusing to obey Yahweh is spoken of as turning away from a good path. AT: "leave good and go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here wicked ways are spoken of as if they were a path that is not straight. AT: "their wicked ways" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
People are lead away in order to punish them. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "lead them away to punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
